did.unittitle: Bound Manuscripts collection
did.abstract: The bound manuscripts collection consists of over 700 manuscripts from the 7th to the 19th century and covers a wide variety of topics. The collection includes a papyrus fragment from the 7th century, a North French or Flemish Book of hours (late 15th or early 16th century), Persian and Arabic manuscripts, manuscript books from the 16th through 18th century, commonplace books, Friendship albums, and personal journals.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Armenian Bible 170/466 available on microfilm with portions available on color slides. Original not available for consultation due to fragile condition.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Bound Manuscripts collection (Collection 170). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of bound manuscripts of varying contents most notable for its early material which includes a papyrus fragment from the 7th century, a vellum Breviary (French, 15th century), a North French or Flemish Book of hours (late 15th or early 16th century), Persian and Arabic manuscripts, manuscript books from the 16th through 18th century, commonplace books, Friendship albums, and personal journals.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Armenian Bible 170/466 available on microfilm with portions available on color slides. Original not available for consultation due to fragile condition.

altformavail.head: Online Items Available
altformavail.p: Portions of this collection have been digitized and are available online: Bound Manuscripts Collection (16 items).

Der Annder Thaill. Nürembergische Cronica Nuremberg ). **Chronicle listing events from 1530 to 1627. Numerous coats of arms and watercolour paintings of a float and a participant from the 1539 carnival.

Empereurs, rois et princes regnants du 18e siècle ). Phillipps Manuscript no.10610. Chronology of the states of Europe, 1700-1745, with lists of rules from the late 17th century to 1748. At end is a short chronology of France, 1515/1709.

Commonplace Book. (French ). **Phillipps Manuscript no.2500. The first and longest item (22 leaves) is Les enluminures du jeu de la constitution.

Four large decorated initials. Bound in full calf over oak boards; 4 brass bosses; painting on front cover of the deposition of Christ dated Toledo 1694. Belonged to the Franciscans of Seville.
Besant, Walter. A Fountain Sealed.
Doudney, Sarah (1843-1926). A Romance of Lincoln's Inn.
Los Angeles Police Department (). Accompanied by related matter.
Payn, James (1830-1898). A Country Family.
A dictionary of philosophical and theological terms in alphabetical order, untitled, Italy, Written by three people.
did.physdesc: Paper. 157 leaves. Covers lacking, sewn on 3 split bands.

did.unittitle: Prayer. Arabic.
Qur'an. Scribe: Hafiz Muhammad 'Arif ab Sakuni.
Mulla 'Ubaydullah. Persian poem (Du'a').
Qur'an (portion: al-Mulk). Surah Yasin 'Amm Al-Fath, al-Wagi'ah E.
Naokh Ta 'liq, 'Amir 'Ali al-Tabrizi style with poem. Farsi.
Qur'an (portion: Surat Yasin, al-Fath, al-Wagi 'ah and Tabarak).
Qur'an. Fragment in unbound sections. s. X.
Christian prayers. Arabic, s. XVIII?

Quadragesimale, ca 50 anonymous sermons on the Gospels for Lent and Good Friday. German s. XV med. Written by one person in an uneven hybrid script. Bound in contemporary tawed hide over beveled oak boards. Pastedowns: front, canon law s. XIII, back, grammars. XV.

Biblical Miscellany. North-East Italy, Includes Genealogia beate Virginis. Liber generationis Ihesu Christi; Alexandre de Ville Dieu, Summarium Biblicum; etc. Written by one person in hybrida and textura scripts.
did.physdesc: Paper (thick). 20 leaves. Bound in quarter leather over bare beveled oak boards.

did.unittitle: Centum meditationes passionis domini Ihesu Christi. Latin and German. Cologne, Germany, s. XV med. Written by one person in a well formed hybrida script. Probably belonged to the Carthusians of St Barbara in Cologne to judge from the binding stamps and the saints mentioned. Signature of Pastor Servius Jacobo Rus[...?], s. XVII.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 220 leaves. Bound in contemporary blind stamp calf over wooden boards, single brass fore-edge clasp, back to front.

did.unittitle: Bede, Commentarius in Cantica Canticorum vol.7.6-7. South Italy, s. XI 3/4. Written in Bari Type Beneventan script. Name (s. XIII): Petro de Caponisso, on leaf. Removed from a printed book: G. Savonarola, Confessionale, Venice , and Matthaeus Corradonus, Speculum confessorum et lumen conscientie, Venice 1535 (UCLA 121963 AMEIP), from the abbey of SS. Flora and Lucilla, O.S.B., Arezzo (Ex libris).

Diurnal. Devotional prayers in Latin and Dutch with Ferial Psalter. The Netherlands (N. Holland) Daily offices of the Temporale and the Sanctorale, without Matins; Ferial Psalter; Common of the Saints.

Prayer book in Latin and German, Germany (Goslar?), Portions of two separate prayer books joined together in the early 16th century. Part 1: probably Augustinian house in the diocese of Hildesheim, perhaps in Goslar, to judge from the saints in the first calendar. Note: illumination by the same artists in a manuscript dated 1499 (see H. Tenschert, Lauchtendes Mittelalters 21, 1989, no.49, pp.310-14). Bound in 16th century brown morocco, rebacked, with gilt stamp of Mary in the center of the front and back covers. Ex libris: Frances Paget, cleric (1830); Edward Crawshaw (book label); Sotheby's December 20, 1920, no.105.
[Shahjahan, Emperor of India.] Muntakhab al-lughab [s. XVIII?].
Razi, Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Zakariya, 865?-925? Kitab-i Mansuri.
[Anonymous prayers to the virgin Mary and to various saints]. (s. XVIII). In Amharic. Gift of Dr. Daniel Solomon, 1982.
Taylor, Z.C. (Zacary Clay), The Rise and Progress of Baptist Missions in Brazil: an Autobiography / by Z.C. Taylor, [Texas: Z.C. Taylor, ].
did.physdesc: 206 leaves. Carbon copy. Bound in mottled boards with buckram(?) spine.

did.unittitle: Prayer book, Hildesheim. ().
A Trip to the West Indies.
Book of Hours in Middle Dutch. North-east Netherlands, Written by one person in an angular hybrida.
did.physdesc: Paper. 209 leaves. 25 large decorated initials. Bound in calf over oak boards, rebacked.

did.unittitle: Book of Hours (Use of Utrecht). Arnhem, Brabant, s. XV ex. Written by one person in an upright hybrida script. Bookplate of Gordon H. Craine.
did.physdesc: Paper and parchment. 158 leaves. Colored woodcut of Saint Roch inserted after f. 46. Bound in modern brown calf.

did.unittitle: Thoma, Richard. Lambda. Contains manuscripts of all his poems except the Promised Land.
did.physdesc: 1 vol. with pen and ink drawings and decorations.

did.unittitle: Office of the Dead. Notated. Italy, Written and signed by presbyter Johannes Jacobus for a religious confraterity founded in 1361. Music on a five-line staff. Text written in a round Italian textura.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 32 leaves. Bound in 17th century tooled red calf with heraldic device of Alexander Guidiccioni, bishop of Lucca (1549-1605), rebacked, spine laid down. Old press mark XIX.A.17.

did.unittitle: Deposition in Latin and Italian. Venice, Between Caterino Rosso and her sons Nicoletus and Tibaldus and her sons by a previous marriage, Ptrus Arbusian and his brother Franciscus, who are accused of having built a wall illegally on her property in the district of San Silvestro causing damage to her well. Heard in Torcello (Venice) before Mattheus Aymo and Antonius Michael and Andreas Marcello (in absentia), judges.

Notary's cartulary. Venice, Mestre, Copies of about 60 documents in 2 chronological sequences, the first dating , the second dating from , involving properties of the Gritti family. Written by one person in a well formed notarial cursive script.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 109 leaves. Bound in 16th century parchment over boards.

did.unittitle: Book of Hours (Use of Rome). North-East France, s. XV ex. Written by one person in an upright hybrida script. A tiny and attractive pocket prayer book when it was new.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 102 leaves. Bound in dark brown leather over paper boards. Thirteen (7-9 line) initials painted or in gold or on painted or gold grounds.

did.unittitle: Guibert de Tournai O.F.M., Liber Pharetra. Bologna (?), Italy, s. XIII2/2. Written by one person in a small Italian gothic textura. Two illuminated initials (including f. 128 head of Gregory IX).
did.physdesc: Parchment. 161 leaves. Bound in 20th century calf over boards in imitation of a medieval binding.

did.unittitle: Barros, André de (1675-1754). Vida do Apostolico padre Antonio Vieyra. Folio s. XVIII.
Koran ().
Catalogous Neuer Curieuser Buecher de Anno

Calendar from a liturgical book. St Jean de Baillon, Parchment 18 leaves. Title and heading by Francis Denis Beautort. 12 large initials in red ink. Signed, dated and written (probably the calendar rather than the added notes) by Father Denis Beautort, priest of the church of St Jean de Baillon (near Luzarches, north of Paris toward Chantilly).
did.physdesc: In a contemporary limp parchment wrapper too small for the calendar.

did.unittitle: Prayers. In French and Latin. North-west France (Brittany?), Written by one person in an angular French textura script.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 48 leaves. 59 gold initials on blue, red and white grounds, 6 grotesque initials. Bound in 18th century Italian colored paper covers embossed with flowers. Formerly part of a larger manuscript.

did.unittitle: Statutes and Ordinances of the Order of St Michael. In French. France (probably Paris), Written by one person in batarde script. Full page miniature (f. 7) with architectural border of a king (originally Louis XI, now Francis I) enthroned and attended by his court. Attributed to a painter in the circle of the Master of the Paris Entries, possibly Etienne Collaud. One of a series of twelve manuscripts of the Statutes commmissioned by Francis I between 1523 and 1528. Bookplate of Hemricout de Ramiol (ca 1810, Liege), and Howel Wills (1845-1901). Sotheby's July 11, 1894, no.1104, bought by Ellis.
did.physdesc: Parchment. 42 leaves. Bound in dark blue velvet over pasteboards, bront and back detached.

did.unittitle: Document roll. Pisa(?), Italy, 1326-27. A commercial agreement in Italian. Sold by Bonhams & Brooks March 13, 2001, no.429.
